Award.AwardTitle: Molecular structures and dynamics at interfaces probed with heterodyne detected 2D SFG spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Martin T. Zanni of the University of Wisconsin - Madison and his graduate and undergraduate research students are investigating the chemical structures of molecules at interfaces. They do this using heterodyne detected, two-dimensional, sum-frequency generation spectroscopy. Specific molecules to be studied include small organometallic species and biomolecules.

The ultimate goal of the work by Professor Zanni and his group is to develop powerful new methods to probe the structure and behavior of complex molecules at interfaces. Interfaces are ubiquitous in nature, including the surfaces of cells. The development of experimental methods that are only sensitive to chemical species at the surface has been important in developing a better understanding of the chemistry in this unique milieu. Along the way, Prof. Zanni will build a strong, interdisciplinary program in physical chemistry and will train a new generation of researchers for the technological workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the development of a new type of spectroscopy, called heterodyne detected 2-dimensional sum frequency generation (HD 2D SFG) spectroscopy.  Spectroscopies are techniques that use light to identify or study molecules and substances. It can be very difficult to characterize even very simple molecules, because they are so small that they cannot be seen with light microscopes. Spectroscopy is used to infer molecular structures from the way in which they absorb light. It is especiallly difficult to characterize molecules on surfaces, like metals or on top of liquids or on membranes like in cells, because then there are very few molecules and lots of signals from molecules in solution that are not at the interface. In this grant, we developed HD 2D SFG, as a new way of studying molecules at interfaces.  It combines two very successful techniques - 2D Infrared spectroscopy and SFG spectroscopy.  2D IR spectroscopy probes molecular structures by looking at the way in which molecules vibrate, like balls connected by springs. SFG spectroscopy uses an optics trick to only measure molecules at interfaces. Putting them together, we get a 2D IR spectrum of only molecules at interfaces.  In this grant period, we published a series of papers reporting HD 2D SFG spectra of small proteins (peptides) on interfaces of gold and gold covered with a hydrogen bonding materials.  Peptides sticking to gold is important for understand because it is the way that muscles and other creatures attached to rocks and boats. Hydrogen bonding is important because it can influence binding as well.  We discovered that a peptide adopts a helical structure on a surface and that we could identify the regions that were disordered even though our spectroscopy shouldn't have been able to.  We also studied DNA on gold surfaces.  Segments of DNA are used as sensors, but their thermodynamics are altered on surfaces for reasons not entirely understood.  We published a very detailed strutural characterization, determining the angle and tilt of the DNA bands that extend from the surface.  Throughtout these experiments, we developed the theoretical understanding of this new spectroscopy and made improvements to is parent technique 2D IR spectroscopy as well.  Our efforts have helped to better understand the chemistry of molecular binding at interfaces and helped to create a state-of-the-art technique to be used by scientists worldwide.
